challenges-to-voters-at-the-polling-plac.name: Challenges to Voters at the Polling Place

subtopics.fact: Any registered voter, election official, or poll watcher may challenge a voter.
Challenges are permitted at the polling place on Election Day.
subtopics.subtopic: What are the restrictions on polling place challenges?

subtopics.fact: A voter may be challenged on the basis of their identity or their residence.
subtopics.subtopic: What are the allowed reasons on which a voter can be challenged?
Is there a requirement for the challenger to provide cause or evidence?

subtopics.fact: If challenged, a voter must produce another registered voter from their county who can vouch for their identity and residence.
subtopics.subtopic: How does a voter defend their eligibility to vote if they are challenged?

subtopics.fact:
All voters will be asked, but not required, to show an acceptable photo ID on Election Day. 

Note: On October 2nd, 2012, a judge postponed the new voter ID law implementation stating there was not enough time to ensure that some voters would not be disenfranchised. The law will go into effect in 2013.
subtopics.subtopic: Who must show ID to vote?

subtopics.fact: Acceptable photo IDs include: * A PA driver's license. Must be currently valid, or expired less than 12 months at the time a voter is casting a vote. * An ID issued by PennDOT. Must be currently valid, or expired less than 12 months at the time a voter is casting a vote. * A U.S. Passport. Must have an expiration date. Expiration date must be after 11/6/12. * An active duty or retired U.S. military ID, including an ID for members of the PA National Guard. No expiration date required. * A military dependent's ID. Must have an expiration date. Expiration date must be after 11/6/12. * An employee ID issued by federal, PA state, PA county, or PA municipal government. A school district ID is NOT acceptable. Must have an expiration date. Expiration date must be after 11/6/12. * An ID issued by an accredited PA university, college, seminary, community college, or two-year college to students, faculty, employees and alumni. Must have an expiration date. Expiration date must be after 11/6/12. NOTE: many university-related IDs do not have expiration dates, and so will NOT be eligible IDs. * An ID issued by a PA care facility (such as a long-term care nursing facility, assisted living residence or a personal care home). Must have an expiration date. Expiration date must be after 11/6/12.

Any voter without proper ID can still cast a regular ballot.  If the voter is unable to show proof of residency, the voter may vote a provisional ballot. Their vote will be counted, as long as the voter returns a copy of their acceptable ID and affirmation letter to their county within 6 calendar days.  Affirmations and copies of ID may be returned to the county in person, by mail, fax or via email.
subtopics.subtopic: If a voter has no ID, are there alternatives such as an oath or witness?

subtopics.fact: Yes, as long as it is valid and contains a photo of the voter.
subtopics.subtopic: Is a student ID an acceptable form of identification?

subtopics.fact: Not necessarily, but the ID must be valid (so if the ID not showing the voter's current address makes it invalid according to the issuing agency, the ID is unacceptable).
subtopics.subtopic: Does the address on the ID have to match the address at which the voter is registered?
